entries.meaning: (followed by a location) Precisely and forcefully.
examples: He dropped his bag of tools plonk in the middle of the table.

entries.meaning: (countable) The sound of something solid landing.
examples: I just heard a plonk – did something fall down in the kitchen?

verbs.description: plonk (third-person singular simple present plonks, present participle plonking, simple past and past participle plonked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set or toss (something) down carelessly.
examples: When you’ve finished with the sponge, just plonk it back in the sink.

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To sit down heavily and without ceremony.
(transitive, Internet slang) To automatically ignore a particular poster.
examples: I got tired of his trolling and ad hominem attacks, so I plonked him.

description: From WWI military slang, derived by alteration of French vin blanc (“white wine”) by the law of Hobson-Jobson. Recorded earliest in the playful rhyming slang form plinketty-plonk. Possibly influenced by the sound of wine being poured into a glass.

entries.meaning: (uncountable, UK, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, informal) Cheap or inferior everyday wine.
examples: The third category of wines is highly unattractive as these may only be sold as generic wines (white, red or rosé), without reference to any geographical location. Only surplus plonk and cooking wine would aspire to fall in this segment, which can be blended with any other wine - to any extent.

entries.meaning: (countable, derogatory, Britain, law enforcement slang) A female police constable. [in the 1970s]
examples: Chris and that plonk had better be flushing the scum out.
